Access ETN data using the etn R package

Stijn Van Hoey

2021-03-16

Source: vignettes/etn.Rmd
etn.Rmd

Introduction

The etn package provides a set of get_*-based functions to access the ETN data and metadata. In this vignette a quick overview of these main functions is given. As the access to data is linked to specific user profiles, keep in mind that the results can be different for other users.

To start, load the package:

library(etn)

When not installed, do not forget to install the package using the devtools package:

if (!"devtools" %in% installed.packages()) install.packages("devtools")
devtools::install_github("inbo/etn")

The database connection

In order to access the data, the first step is always to connect with your user credentials (as received by VLIZ) to the database.

con <- connect_to_etn(Sys.getenv("userid"), Sys.getenv("pwd"))

Remark that for this example, we load the user credentials as environmental variables by saving an .Renviron file in the home directory with the username and password stored. Other options are available as well, as explained here.

Once the connection established, the get_* functions can be used to effectively access the data. Each of these functions have a (valid database) connection as first input.

Notice, that you can find the get_*-functions inside Rstudio by typing: etn::get_* + TAB button.

Metadata

Project overview

To get a full overview of the projects you have access to, use the function get_projects():

my_projects <- get_projects(con)
head(my_projects, 10) # print 10 first
#> # A tibble: 10 x 15
#>       pk project_code project_type application_type telemetry_type project_name
#>    <int> <chr>        <chr>        <chr>            <chr>          <chr>       
#>  1   793 2004_Gudena  animal       acoustic_telemeâ€¦ Acoustic       2004_Gudena 
#>  2   794 2004_Gudena  network      acoustic_telemeâ€¦ Acoustic       2004_Gudena 
#>  3    16 2010_phd_reâ€¦ animal       acoustic_telemeâ€¦ Acoustic       2010_phd_reâ€¦
#>  4   841 2010_phd_reâ€¦ animal       acoustic_telemeâ€¦ Acoustic       2010_phd_reâ€¦
#>  5   760 2011_Loire   animal       acoustic_telemeâ€¦ Acoustic       2011_Loire  
#>  6   761 2011_Loire   network      acoustic_telemeâ€¦ Acoustic       2011_Loire  
#>  7    20 2011_rivierâ€¦ animal       acoustic_telemeâ€¦ Acoustic       2011 Rivierâ€¦
#>  8   755 2011_Warnow  network      acoustic_telemeâ€¦ Acoustic       2011_Warnow 
#>  9   754 2011_Warnow  animal       acoustic_telemeâ€¦ Acoustic       2011_Warnow 
#> 10    15 2012_leopolâ€¦ animal       acoustic_telemeâ€¦ Acoustic       2012 Leopolâ€¦
#> # â€¦ with 9 more variables: coordinating_organization <chr>,
#> #   principal_investigator <chr>, principal_investigator_email <chr>,
#> #   start_date <date>, end_date <date>, latitude <dbl>, longitude <dbl>,
#> #   moratorium <chr>, imis_dataset_id <int>

As projects are defined both on the level of the animal as well as the network, a column type is available that defines the type of project (animal or network). Still, one can also directly subset by adding the type as input argument, e.g.Â for network:

my_network_projects <- get_projects(con, project_type = "network")
head(my_network_projects, 10) # print 10 first
#> # A tibble: 10 x 15
#>       pk project_code project_type application_type telemetry_type project_name
#>    <int> <chr>        <chr>        <chr>            <chr>          <chr>       
#>  1   794 2004_Gudena  network      acoustic_telemeâ€¦ Acoustic       2004_Gudena 
#>  2   761 2011_Loire   network      acoustic_telemeâ€¦ Acoustic       2011_Loire  
#>  3   755 2011_Warnow  network      acoustic_telemeâ€¦ Acoustic       2011_Warnow 
#>  4   758 2013_Foyle   network      acoustic_telemeâ€¦ Acoustic       2013_Foyle  
#>  5   802 2014_Frome   network      acoustic_telemeâ€¦ Acoustic       2014_Frome  
#>  6   819 2014_Nene    network      acoustic_telemeâ€¦ Acoustic       2014_Nene   
#>  7   815 2015_PhD_Guâ€¦ network      acoustic_telemeâ€¦ Acoustic       2015_PhD_Guâ€¦
#>  8   773 2016_Diacciâ€¦ network      acoustic_telemeâ€¦ PIT            2016_Diacciâ€¦
#>  9   763 2017_Fremur  network      acoustic_telemeâ€¦ Acoustic       2017_Fremur 
#> 10   764 2019_Grotenâ€¦ network      acoustic_telemeâ€¦ Acoustic       2019_Grotenâ€¦
#> # â€¦ with 9 more variables: coordinating_organization <chr>,
#> #   principal_investigator <chr>, principal_investigator_email <chr>,
#> #   start_date <date>, end_date <date>, latitude <dbl>, longitude <dbl>,
#> #   moratorium <chr>, imis_dataset_id <int>

If you want just to retrieve the network/animal projects names, you can use the list_network_project_codes(con)/list_animal_project_codes(con):

list_network_project_codes(con)

Check the list parameter options for all list_*() available functions.

Receiver overview

A network project typically considers multiple receivers that are placed on specific locations to lay out the network. To get an overview of receivers deployments linked to specific projects, use the get_deployments function:

ws3_deployments <- get_deployments(con, network_project_code = "ws3")
head(ws3_deployments, 10) # print 10 first
#> # A tibble: 7 x 39
#>      pk receiver_id application_type network_projectâ€¦ station_name
#>   <int> <chr>       <chr>            <chr>            <chr>       
#> 1 10017 VR2W-127735 acoustic_telemeâ€¦ ws3              ws-42A      
#> 2  6180 VR2W-127737 acoustic_telemeâ€¦ ws3              ws-53       
#> 3 10022 VR2W-127032 acoustic_telemeâ€¦ ws3              ws-53A      
#> 4 10020 VR2W-127734 acoustic_telemeâ€¦ ws3              ws-55       
#> 5 10004 VR2W-115439 acoustic_telemeâ€¦ ws3              ws-F42      
#> 6 10015 VR2W-127722 acoustic_telemeâ€¦ ws3              ws-F53      
#> 7 10016 VR2W-127725 acoustic_telemeâ€¦ ws3              ws-HW6      
#> # â€¦ with 34 more variables: station_description <chr>, station_manager <chr>,
#> #   deploy_date_time <dttm>, deploy_latitude <dbl>, deploy_longitude <dbl>,
#> #   intended_latitude <dbl>, intended_longitude <dbl>, mooring_type <chr>,
#> #   bottom_depth <chr>, riser_length <chr>, deploy_depth <chr>,
#> #   battery_installation_date <dttm>, battery_estimated_end_date <dttm>,
#> #   activation_date_time <dttm>, recover_date_time <dttm>,
#> #   recover_latitude <dbl>, recover_longitude <dbl>, download_date_time <dttm>,
#> #   download_file_name <chr>, valid_data_until_date_time <dttm>,
#> #   sync_date_time <dttm>, time_drift <chr>,
#> #   ar_battery_installation_date <dttm>, ar_confirm <chr>,
#> #   transmit_profile <chr>, transmit_power_output <chr>,
#> #   log_temperature_stats_period <int>, log_temperature_sample_period <int>,
#> #   log_tilt_sample_period <int>, log_noise_stats_period <int>,
#> #   log_noise_sample_period <int>, log_depth_stats_period <int>,
#> #   log_depth_sample_period <int>, comments <chr>

You can also define multiple (network) projects at the same time, by combining them in a vector:

ws_deployments <- get_deployments(con, network_project_code = c("ws1", "ws3"))
head(ws_deployments, 10) # print 10 first
#> # A tibble: 10 x 39
#>       pk receiver_id application_type network_projectâ€¦ station_name
#>    <int> <chr>       <chr>            <chr>            <chr>       
#>  1 10722 VR2W-136469 acoustic_telemeâ€¦ ws1              ws-DL7      
#>  2  9512 VR2W-136466 acoustic_telemeâ€¦ ws1              ws-DL9      
#>  3 11527 VR2W-137076 acoustic_telemeâ€¦ ws1              ws-DL9      
#>  4  6038 VR2W-123821 acoustic_telemeâ€¦ ws1              ws-GVWSP    
#>  5  9488 VR2W-114258 acoustic_telemeâ€¦ ws1              ws-GVWSP    
#>  6 10343 VR2W-123832 acoustic_telemeâ€¦ ws1              ws-OG10     
#>  7 10342 VR2W-123831 acoustic_telemeâ€¦ ws1              ws-OGDL     
#>  8 10720 VR2W-136465 acoustic_telemeâ€¦ ws1              ws-SP3      
#>  9  9490 VR2W-134900 acoustic_telemeâ€¦ ws1              ws-STEEN    
#> 10 10344 VR2W-131002 acoustic_telemeâ€¦ ws1              ws-TRAWL    
#> # â€¦ with 34 more variables: station_description <chr>, station_manager <chr>,
#> #   deploy_date_time <dttm>, deploy_latitude <dbl>, deploy_longitude <dbl>,
#> #   intended_latitude <dbl>, intended_longitude <dbl>, mooring_type <chr>,
#> #   bottom_depth <chr>, riser_length <chr>, deploy_depth <chr>,
#> #   battery_installation_date <dttm>, battery_estimated_end_date <dttm>,
#> #   activation_date_time <dttm>, recover_date_time <dttm>,
#> #   recover_latitude <dbl>, recover_longitude <dbl>, download_date_time <dttm>,
#> #   download_file_name <chr>, valid_data_until_date_time <dttm>,
#> #   sync_date_time <dttm>, time_drift <chr>,
#> #   ar_battery_installation_date <dttm>, ar_confirm <chr>,
#> #   transmit_profile <chr>, transmit_power_output <chr>,
#> #   log_temperature_stats_period <int>, log_temperature_sample_period <int>,
#> #   log_tilt_sample_period <int>, log_noise_stats_period <int>,
#> #   log_noise_sample_period <int>, log_depth_stats_period <int>,
#> #   log_depth_sample_period <int>, comments <chr>

When a number of columns is not useful to your specific purpose, remember that the output is a data.frame, which can be filtered and subsetted conveniently with for example the dplyr functions.

library(dplyr)
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter, lag
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

For example, selecting only the columns receiver_id and station_name:

ws_deployments %>%
  select(receiver_id, station_name) %>%
  head(10) # print 10 first
#> # A tibble: 10 x 2
#>    receiver_id station_name
#>    <chr>       <chr>       
#>  1 VR2W-136469 ws-DL7      
#>  2 VR2W-136466 ws-DL9      
#>  3 VR2W-137076 ws-DL9      
#>  4 VR2W-123821 ws-GVWSP    
#>  5 VR2W-114258 ws-GVWSP    
#>  6 VR2W-123832 ws-OG10     
#>  7 VR2W-123831 ws-OGDL     
#>  8 VR2W-136465 ws-SP3      
#>  9 VR2W-134900 ws-STEEN    
#> 10 VR2W-131002 ws-TRAWL

Deployments overview

Receivers are deployed for a specific period and this deployment information can be accessed as well with the command get_deployments. To know the status of each receiver, join with information from get_receivers():

my_deployments <- get_deployments(con, network_project_code = "ws1")

# Get list of receivers
receiver_ids <- my_deployments %>% distinct(receiver_id) %>% pull()

# Find receivers that are broken or lost
broken_receiver_ids <-
  get_receivers(con, receiver_id = receiver_ids, status = c("Broken", "Lost")) %>%
  pull(receiver_id)

# Filter deployments on those with broken or lost receivers
my_deployments %>%
  filter(receiver_id %in% broken_receiver_ids) %>%
  head() # print 10 first
#> # A tibble: 2 x 39
#>      pk receiver_id application_type network_projectâ€¦ station_name
#>   <int> <chr>       <chr>            <chr>            <chr>       
#> 1  9512 VR2W-136466 acoustic_telemeâ€¦ ws1              ws-DL9      
#> 2  9494 VR2W-134894 acoustic_telemeâ€¦ ws1              ws-WN2      
#> # â€¦ with 34 more variables: station_description <chr>, station_manager <chr>,
#> #   deploy_date_time <dttm>, deploy_latitude <dbl>, deploy_longitude <dbl>,
#> #   intended_latitude <dbl>, intended_longitude <dbl>, mooring_type <chr>,
#> #   bottom_depth <chr>, riser_length <chr>, deploy_depth <chr>,
#> #   battery_installation_date <dttm>, battery_estimated_end_date <dttm>,
#> #   activation_date_time <dttm>, recover_date_time <dttm>,
#> #   recover_latitude <dbl>, recover_longitude <dbl>, download_date_time <dttm>,
#> #   download_file_name <chr>, valid_data_until_date_time <dttm>,
#> #   sync_date_time <dttm>, time_drift <chr>,
#> #   ar_battery_installation_date <dttm>, ar_confirm <chr>,
#> #   transmit_profile <chr>, transmit_power_output <chr>,
#> #   log_temperature_stats_period <int>, log_temperature_sample_period <int>,
#> #   log_tilt_sample_period <int>, log_noise_stats_period <int>,
#> #   log_noise_sample_period <int>, log_depth_stats_period <int>,
#> #   log_depth_sample_period <int>, comments <chr>

Animals overview

Within an animal project, multiple animals are provided with a transmitter. The metadata of these animals is requested with the function get_animals. As animals can be part of both network and animal projects, both can be used to filter the results.

As such, selecting the animals metadata for the 2012_leopoldkanaal project:

my_animals <- get_animals(con, animal_project_code = "2012_leopoldkanaal")
head(my_animals, 10) # print 10 first
#> # A tibble: 10 x 64
#>       pk animal_id animal_project_â€¦ tag_id tag_fk scientific_name common_name
#>    <int>     <int> <chr>            <chr>  <chr>  <chr>           <chr>      
#>  1   478       478 2012_leopoldkanâ€¦ A69-1â€¦ 194    Anguilla anguiâ€¦ European eâ€¦
#>  2   486       486 2012_leopoldkanâ€¦ A69-1â€¦ 202    Anguilla anguiâ€¦ European eâ€¦
#>  3   487       487 2012_leopoldkanâ€¦ A69-1â€¦ 203    Anguilla anguiâ€¦ European eâ€¦
#>  4   483       483 2012_leopoldkanâ€¦ A69-1â€¦ 199    Anguilla anguiâ€¦ European eâ€¦
#>  5   485       485 2012_leopoldkanâ€¦ A69-1â€¦ 201    Anguilla anguiâ€¦ European eâ€¦
#>  6   473       473 2012_leopoldkanâ€¦ A69-1â€¦ 189    Anguilla anguiâ€¦ European eâ€¦
#>  7   482       482 2012_leopoldkanâ€¦ A69-1â€¦ 198    Anguilla anguiâ€¦ European eâ€¦
#>  8   477       477 2012_leopoldkanâ€¦ A69-1â€¦ 193    Anguilla anguiâ€¦ European eâ€¦
#>  9   481       481 2012_leopoldkanâ€¦ A69-1â€¦ 197    Anguilla anguiâ€¦ European eâ€¦
#> 10   476       476 2012_leopoldkanâ€¦ A69-1â€¦ 192    Anguilla anguiâ€¦ European eâ€¦
#> # â€¦ with 57 more variables: aphia_id <int>, animal_label <chr>,
#> #   animal_nickname <chr>, tagger <chr>, capture_date_time <dttm>,
#> #   capture_location <chr>, capture_latitude <dbl>, capture_longitude <dbl>,
#> #   capture_method <chr>, capture_depth <chr>,
#> #   capture_temperature_change <chr>, release_date_time <dttm>,
#> #   release_location <chr>, release_latitude <dbl>, release_longitude <dbl>,
#> #   recapture_date_time <dttm>, length1_type <chr>, length1 <dbl>,
#> #   length1_unit <chr>, length2_type <chr>, length2 <dbl>, length2_unit <chr>,
#> #   length3_type <chr>, length3 <dbl>, length3_unit <chr>, length4_type <chr>,

#> #   age <dbl>, age_unit <chr>, sex <chr>, life_stage <chr>,

#> #   dna_sample <chr>, sedative <chr>, sedative_concentration <chr>,

#> #   buffer_concentration_in_anaesthetic <chr>,
#> #   anaesthetic_concentration_in_recirculation <chr>,
#> #   buffer_concentration_in_recirculation <chr>, dissolved_oxygen <chr>,
#> #   pre_surgery_holding_period <chr>, post_surgery_holding_period <chr>,
#> #   holding_temperature <chr>, comments <chr>

To minimize spelling errors, the etn functions are case insensitive. An example:

my_animals_case_check <- get_animals(con, animal_project_code = "2012_LEopoLdkAnAaL")
identical(my_animals, my_animals_case_check)
#> [1] TRUE

Transmitter overview

The transmitters/tags metadata can be accessed by the get_tags function:

my_tags <- get_tags(con)
head(my_tags, 10) # print 10 first
#> # A tibble: 10 x 45
#>       pk tag_id tag_id_alternatâ€¦ telemetry_type manufacturer model frequency
#>    <int> <chr>  <chr>            <chr>          <chr>        <chr> <chr>

#>  2 15631 416kHâ€¦ <NA>             acoustic       LOTEK        L-AMâ€¦ 416.7    
#>  3 15515 416kHâ€¦ <NA>             acoustic       LOTEK        L-AMâ€¦ 416.7    
#>  4 15636 416kHâ€¦ <NA>             acoustic       LOTEK        L-AMâ€¦ 416.7    
#>  5 15680 416kHâ€¦ <NA>             acoustic       LOTEK        L-AMâ€¦ 416.7    
#>  6 15656 416kHâ€¦ <NA>             acoustic       LOTEK        L-AMâ€¦ 416.7    
#>  7 15681 416kHâ€¦ <NA>             acoustic       LOTEK        L-AMâ€¦ 416.7    
#>  8 15682 416kHâ€¦ <NA>             acoustic       LOTEK        L-AMâ€¦ 416.7

#> #   step4_duration <int>, step4_acceleration_duration <int>

Detections data

The raw detections are the core for any type of analysis and access is provided by the get_detections function. Different filters are available which you can explore by typing ?get_detections in the console. To narrow down the data request, filters are provided on animal/network project name, the deployment station name and the transmitter identifier to narrow. Furthermore, as these data sets can be large, some additional time-based filters are provided with a start_date and an end_date:

my_detections <- get_detections(con,
  animal_project_code = "2010_phd_reubens",
  start_date = "2011-01-28",
  end_date = "2011-02-01",
  limit = TRUE # Limit number of records for this example
)
head(my_detections, 10) # print 10 first
#> # A tibble: 10 x 23
#>        pk date_time           receiver_id application_type network_projectâ€¦
#>     <int> <dttm>              <chr>       <chr>            <chr>           
#>  1 2.01e7 2011-01-29 02:49:33 VR2W-110781 acoustic_telemeâ€¦ thornton        
#>  2 2.01e7 2011-01-29 03:00:28 VR2W-110781 acoustic_telemeâ€¦ thornton        
#>  3 2.01e7 2011-01-30 17:30:52 VR2W-110781 acoustic_telemeâ€¦ thornton        
#>  4 2.01e7 2011-01-30 17:40:27 VR2W-110781 acoustic_telemeâ€¦ thornton        
#>  5 2.01e7 2011-01-30 18:00:01 VR2W-110781 acoustic_telemeâ€¦ thornton        
#>  6 2.01e7 2011-01-30 18:25:51 VR2W-110781 acoustic_telemeâ€¦ thornton        
#>  7 2.01e7 2011-01-31 03:48:31 VR2W-110781 acoustic_telemeâ€¦ thornton        
#>  8 2.01e7 2011-01-31 05:08:15 VR2W-110781 acoustic_telemeâ€¦ thornton        
#>  9 2.01e7 2011-01-31 05:11:49 VR2W-110781 acoustic_telemeâ€¦ thornton        
#> 10 2.01e7 2011-01-31 05:27:38 VR2W-110781 acoustic_telemeâ€¦ thornton        
#> # â€¦ with 18 more variables: tag_id <chr>, tag_fk <int>, animal_id <int>,
#> #   animal_project_code <chr>, scientific_name <chr>, station_name <chr>,
#> #   deploy_latitude <dbl>, deploy_longitude <dbl>, sensor_type <chr>,
#> #   sensor_value <dbl>, sensor_unit <chr>, sensor_value_depth <dbl>,
#> #   sensor_value_acceleration <dbl>, sensor_value_temperature <dbl>,
#> #   signal_to_noise_ratio <int>, source_file <chr>, qc_flag <chr>,
#> #   deployment_fk <int>

The date level can be defined on month (e.g. "2011-01") or year (e.g. "2011") level as well. Finally, for explorative reasons, a hard maximum limit of records to request can help to have a quick glance on the expected data.

See more examples in the function help (remember the ?get_detections).
